description: Haunted by the stalemate and growing unrest, Oksana Lintz decides to share the explosive evidence with trusted neighborhood leaders instead of the Directorate, believing local communities deserve the truth.
Key grassroots organizers quietly review Oksana's evidence. They coordinate to launch public assemblies, setting plans for citizens to present grievances about BCI abuses and referendum tampering.

Neighborhood assemblies, galvanized by the disclosed evidence, hold 'street courts' where residents confront alleged election tampering and BCI-driven injustices. Testimonies and accusations spread quickly, fueling demands for local justice.

Some assemblies issue public judgments against former Council agents and ballot tamperers. Penalties—ranging from community service to enforced exile—differ by district, revealing deep fault lines across Stenograd.

Returning citizens once flagged by the BCI face split reactions: some neighborhoods organize reconciliation events, while others erupt in protest, as the sidelined Council fails to steer the city toward unity.
